title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why an increase in the bald eagle population could lead to a decrease in the osprey population in the short term, such as any of the following:

· Bald eagles and ospreys compete for large fish; if there are more bald eagles, there could be less food available for the ospreys or more competition for prey.

· Bald eagles and ospreys specialize in the same prey, so if there are more bald eagles, there could be less food available for the ospreys or more competition for prey.

The response explains why an increase in the bald eagle population could lead to a decrease in the osprey population in the short term, such as one of the following:

· Bald eagles and ospreys compete for large fish; if there are more bald eagles, there could be less food available for the ospreys or more competition for prey.

· Bald eagles and ospreys specialize in the same prey, so if there are more bald eagles, there could be less food available for the ospreys or more competition for prey.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one environmental problem in the Chesapeake Bay that is directly related to the numerous roads and parking lots in Baltimore, such as any of the following:

· Impervious surfaces can lead to flooding in the rivers that lead to the bay.

· Runoff from roads/parking lots can carry pollutants (sediment, oil, antifreeze, dog poop, litter, etc.) into the bay.

The response describes one environmental problem in the Chesapeake Bay that is directly related to the numerous roads and parking lots in Baltimore, such as one of the following:

· Impervious surfaces can lead to flooding in the rivers that lead to the bay.

· Runoff from roads/parking lots can carry pollutants (sediment, oil, antifreeze, dog poop, litter, etc.) into the bay.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim that proposes a realistic solution to the problem identified in part (e), such as any of the following:

· Replacing traditional pavement with permeable pavement will decrease the volume of runoff.

· Planting trees in median strips/sidewalk boxes will allow for more infiltration and decrease the volume of runoff from roads/parking lots.

· Incorporating urban gardens or buffer strips along waterways or the bay will prevent runoff from roads/parking lots from reaching the bay.

· Controlling litter via stricter fines or litter cleanup programs will decrease the amount of litter working its way into the bay from roadways and/or parking lots.

The response makes a claim that proposes a realistic solution to the problem identified in part (e), such as one of the following:

· Replacing traditional pavement with permeable pavement will decrease the volume of runoff.

· Planting trees in median strips/sidewalk boxes will allow for more infiltration and decrease the volume of runoff from roads/parking lots.

· Incorporating urban gardens or buffer strips along waterways or the bay will prevent runoff from roads/parking lots from reaching the bay.

· Controlling litter via stricter fines or litter cleanup programs will decrease the amount of litter working its way into the bay from roadways and/or parking lots.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one additional benefit that could result from the implementation of the solution proposed in part (f), such as any of the following:

Replacing traditional pavement with permeable pavement (solution in part (f)).

· Increases recharge of aquifers

· Decreases flooding

Planting trees in median strips/sidewalk boxes (solution in part (f)).

· Reduces urban heat island effect

· Improves air quality

· Provides habitat

· Decreases noise pollution

Incorporating urban gardens or buffer strips along waterways or the bay (solution in part (f)).

· Reduces urban heat island effect

· Improves air quality

· Provides locally grown produce that reduces need for transport of food from more distant areas

· Increase infiltration or purifies runoff water

Controlling litter via stricter fines or litter cleanup programs (solution in part (f)).

· Increases tourism

· Decreases vermin

· Decreases mosquito-borne disease

· Prevents flooding (trash may accumulate in and clog drains)

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one unintended consequence of concentrated poultry feeding operations on the biodiversity in the Chesapeake Bay, such as any of the following:

· (Organic) wastes could run off into the bay.

· Nutrients from feces or excess foods could run off into the bay.

· Antibiotics that are often used in such operations could be toxic to some aquatic organisms (e.g., algae).

· Hormones that are often used in such operations could affect growth and reproduction of some aquatic organisms (e.g., frogs, fish).

The response describes one unintended consequence of concentrated poultry feeding operations on the biodiversity in the Chesapeake Bay, such as one of the following:

· (Organic) wastes could run off into the bay.

· Nutrients from feces or excess foods could run off into the bay.

· Antibiotics that are often used in such operations could be toxic to some aquatic organisms (e.g., algae).

· Hormones that are often used in such operations could affect growth and reproduction of some aquatic organisms (e.g., frogs, fish).
